document.title: Le curriculum de l'Ontario Anglais de la 4e à la 8e année

D3D646C82B9E463AB718908AB0E17802.description:
the correct plural of most common nouns(e.g., add es to form the plural of words ending in
s, z, x, sh, and ch).

F835F636C48F471995053CE3F5D4C324.description: commas to separate items in lists, dates, and addresses;

10CA8279B30B45FD9A370EBFFB5A808C.description: the period in declarative and imperative sentences;

EC85768DDB424D00946AEE6499622448.description:
capitalization and punctuation of abbreviations for respectful titles for people (e.g., Mr.,
Ms., Dr.) and, where appropriate, for days, months, and places;

15C6E58D48DA4A5D95712A93A3B38EFF.description: initial capital letters for proper nouns, including the names of days and months;

6E0FE4D39DC34894BA8F22E5873A266A.description: noun-pronoun agreement (person, number, and gender) and subject-verb agreement;

EDC65DBAE3AC41D09FDD25C7C69D61EE.description:
past and present verb tenses in the indicative mood for the most common regular verbs
and for the irregular verbs to be and to have

C5CE3BA33EC041DEA31DF02D16C21CB6.description: common and proper nouns and personal pronouns (e.g., I, you, he) as subjects;

FA3B6BF165644F0D8CBFE392F9EBDE68.description: basic connecting words (e.g., and, then, but) to join simple sentences

7863D0CD3A7949878EAF75845DB6A9AE.description: the affirmative and negative forms of simple declarative and imperative sentences;

1C089B55702743658124DCF46AF8F0B0.description:
identify, with the teacher’s assistance,
their writing strengths, the areas in
which they are experiencing problems,
and the parts of the writing process on
which they need to focus in order to
improve (e.g.,“I spelled almost all my
words correctly, but I had difficulty choosing
a topic. I need to focus on brainstorming to
come up with good ideas”).

D590D905668E4CA7B5EB81F99352F472.description:
produce a clean and legible final draft,
using simple techniques and resources
to format and enhance the presentation,
with a focus on the following:
using headings appropriately to help
organize the text;
using underlining, colour, and/or a
different style of lettering (e.g., printing,
cursive writing, a different font) to
emphasize certain text;
integrating clip art, photos, and/or
diagrams to supplement or to reinforce
information and messages;

1014149C4CDE4E25964EDD66315D37CD.description:
use their knowledge of publishing and production skills and strategies to enhance the
presentation of their work.

3F80480554F643CA885AE8DC35B570B2.description:
edit and proofread their written work,
using reference material (e.g., personal
word lists, visual dictionaries) and guidelines
developed by the teacher (e.g., an
editing checklist specific to the writing task,
a posted class writing guideline), and
applying the language conventions set
out on page 34;

B1298729E9964E789FEBC4E891FC9BCC.description: revise and edit their texts, applying their knowledge of language conventions;

C787F705B25D46FE87780D127FC35B29.description:
produce simple friendly messages in
a variety of media forms (e.g., postcards,
greeting cards, e-invitations), using elements
and techniques (e.g., greetings,
good wishes, illustrations, clip art) that are
characteristic of the form selected;

83907B56016F416188BAE76240769C3A.description:
write simple poems, including acrostic
poems:
using expressive vocabulary related to
a theme;
applying basic elements of the form
(e.g., stanzas) and some simple literary
devices (e.g., alliteration);

3F11CC9474D74364AAC31CDFBD8B0E0D.description:
write simple texts in a variety of forms and for various media, applying their knowledge of
the basic elements and techniques associated with each form;

9EC845FBCD3C4B4EBF17ECD03910BD2A.description:
use a variety of simple pre-writing
strategies independently and as a class
to generate and develop ideas and to
select an appropriate topic or form for
their writing (e.g., independently create a
story web; as a class, brainstorm to generate
a list of topics);

51591F4E8D52418E9A08E893A7075E88.description:
determine, independently or with
guidance from the teacher, the purpose
of and audience for the text they are
planning to create;

ECE7843F31D7471EAF2E09A2C3C0DF09.description:
generate, gather, and organize ideas and information to write for an intended purpose and
audience;

EE0A8A2EA29048FEA405FD06688F5007.description:
draw inferences about the ideas and
messages in a text on the basis of
evidence in the text and their prior
knowledge (e.g., violence in a cartoon may
imply that violence is acceptable in general),
and present a possible alternative
perspective (e.g., retell a cartoon’s story
from a different character’s viewpoint).

2ABA90A0DD5E404F858CFCA31317A591.description:
identify the words and expressions
(e.g., descriptive language in poetry) and
the comparisons (e.g., similes, metaphors)
chosen by authors to evoke clear mental
images and impressions in the minds
of readers

30D6350005DF4BD5B3175824D84E03AB.description:
identify examples of advertisements in
various media that they encounter in
their daily lives, and describe the influence
those advertisements have on
them (e.g., discuss whether advertisements
for toys on cereal boxes increase their desire
to own those toys);

8E0E91E8A8C34B43AFC55232309D637B.description:
develop their own opinions by considering
and comparing ideas and information
presented in texts and relating
the ideas and information to their prior
knowledge, experience, values, and
beliefs;

A9CD3209C86646BA96DCC0A9D23DF34E.description:
demonstrate critical literacy skills by identifying and analysing the messages conveyed by
and perspectives taken in texts, and the techniques used in texts to communicate meaning
and achieve effects.

0943806EDFB74FF3A84D51BDA3526A84.description:
read and view a variety of simple
friendly messages produced in different
media forms (e.g., postcards, greeting cards,
e-invitations), and identify elements and
techniques that are characteristic of
each form (e.g., short messages, illustrations);

32F1145C1BA14A64BC9D3073629BF83A.description:
read a variety of simple procedural
texts (e.g., instructions for a treasure hunt,
directions to the school cafeteria) and identify
their common elements (e.g., imperative
sentences, sequential steps);

AB02AB970B0840589DB8E483D451E425.description:
read a variety of children’s magazines
and identify their common elements
(e.g., word games, short articles, illustrations,
advertisements);

0A29556B742241FEAE29041F931D6D6D.description:
read a variety of narrative and descriptive
paragraphs and identify their purpose,
their structure (e.g., topic sentence,
developing sentences, and concluding sentence),
and some of the characteristics
common to each form (e.g., narrative
paragraphs include connecting words that
indicate the passage of time, descriptive
paragraphs include descriptive vocabulary);

3A881BCD2FBB47BDA3099EBA72AAA88E.description:
read a variety of poems and describe
their form and structure (e.g., in an
acrostic poem, the first letters of the lines of
the poem, listed consecutively, form a word,
often the title of the poem);

B3B8AF2C7820416A85A0119F404AA580.description:
read a variety of story books and other
narrative texts (e.g., graphic novels, folk
tales) and identify their basic elements
(e.g., narrator, characters, main conflict);

38B4FBAC7AC0409EAA39FE4287C4EDA1.description:
identify and describe the form, structure, and elements of a variety of texts, including
elements such as literary devices and other techniques used to enhance a text’s effectiveness;

0903A3D0C75F491696E45D48066EBFAD.description:
retell a story by adapting it, or an
aspect of it, for presentation in another
form (e.g., create a poem about the main
character in a story);

672009B54D0047D3AF3E9AA856BE8D5D.description:
describe the characters in narrative
texts, including their physical traits,
their actions, and the conflicts in which
they are engaged (e.g., human versus
human, human versus nature);

80E290D9BD13479592A61256FE3FDDE2.description:
identify and describe the main events
in narrative texts, presenting them in
sequence

832AE0812E844E99A09EAA22F4C02F9A.description:
identify the important ideas, information,
and messages in literary and
informational texts, restating them in
their own words and providing interpretations,
supported by illustrations
in the text;

591267D3A7234818A3ACA0AE8968C08C.description:
read texts that are appropriate for their
reading level at a sufficient rate and
with sufficient precision and expression
to convey the sense of the text readily
to the reader and to an audience;

7D40FB8B384E46C9BC79D0F6B6039922.description:
monitor and, where necessary, revise
their comprehension of a text (e.g., by
asking questions during and after reading,
such as,“What is causing the pollution in
the river? Did the author tell us earlier in
the article?”);

7D10C183D1394D67855013A238A002BA.description:
use visualization strategies to predict
the meaning of unfamiliar words and
to help them understand the main
ideas, information, and messages in
texts (e.g., create a mental image to determine
the possible meanings of the word
lemur in the sentence,“Put the lemur back
in the cage”)

0FB45D3BE4D446F6B013B20F90ADCCDC.description:
apply their knowledge of French vocabulary
and grammar in a variety of
ways, including the following, to help
them understand texts:
recognize words that are similar in
both languages (e.g., table/table);
find the verb in a sentence;

EAF248A75CBB456D8C7CF74A2EA63BB8.description:
use simple text features (e.g., cover,
illustrations, table of contents) to become
familiar with the general contents of
a text

D5B962CDE681481CBB327317F302815C.description:
make predictions about the content of a
text before and during reading on the
basis of illustrations and other graphic
elements in the text

3B57A4777A1E42DCA987EF16B8B0975F.description:
identify different purposes for reading
(e.g., for pleasure, to obtain information),
and describe the types of texts that are
most appropriate for these purposes;

702BD53A5E8B434EA131DD56D63A97D9.description:
activate their prior knowledge about the
topic of a new text before reading (e.g.,
brainstorm to identify what they already
know about the topic; describe personal
experiences related to the topic);

C4D92FBED52A4D8EB679BD8BA3900F88.description:
identify, with the teacher’s assistance,
their presentation strengths, the areas
in which they are experiencing problems,
and the areas on which they need to
focus in order to improve (e.g.,“I selected
good pictures to go with my presentation,
but I need to spend more time rehearsing
my speech”

C5DDAB70219B4E8B8BFE5B2C86A365DA.description:
use a variety of visual and/or multimedia
aids to enhance their presentations (e.g.,
use appropriate objects to demonstrate a
process, use basic video or audio recording
technology

1242EB7AED5E45F8891140EEDEAFF813.description:
use strategies of effective presentation
that are appropriate for the intended
purpose (e.g., make eye-contact with their
audience when making an important point,
use non-verbal cues such as gestures and
facial expressions to help describe an event
or situation)

CFE417B86677487AAA3AC048C45F7336.description:
deliver a variety of short oral and/or oralvisual
presentations, independently or in
collaboration with other students, incorporating
the characteristics of and techniques
associated with the particular type
of presentation (e.g., make an audio presentation
of a piece of their narrative or
descriptive writing, incorporating sound
effects, or make an audio-visual presentation
of the same work, incorporating both sound
effects and photographs; explain a set of
procedures to a group, using short imperative
sentences delivered in a logical order)

CA284C27CE8B455895B1D77CF47A8936.description:
plan, develop, review, revise, and rehearse
their independent or collaborative oral
and oral-visual presentations (e.g., practise
pronouncing and articulating words before
reciting a poem, plan each group member’s
role in a collaborative presentation)

34031639B6274EBEBBD2429538A6944A.description:
prepare and deliver a variety of short independent and collaborative oral and oral-visual
presentations, using a process approach and applying knowledge of the basic characteristics
and techniques associated with each type of presentation

DD5858D771554FD9BD27A8EA52FCC71A.description:
read aloud with some fluency (i.e.,
attempt a fluid rhythm), focusing on
correct pronunciation, intonation,
and pace (e.g., pausing for commas,
stopping for periods)

DCBF63143C30484CA5B66709C70442BE.description:
use formal and informal language
appropriately in classroom settings

0E16508D5F754CF8A70F7354142DE1A2.description:
identify and distinguish among sounds
in spoken language (e.g., distinguish
between the use of hard and soft consonants
such as c and g , or long and short vowels;
identify vowel digraphs), and imitate
models of correct pronunciation of
familiar vocabulary when speaking

FCBB897C007F45B89BBD957D207A9429.description:
use a simple, logical sequence to communicate
ideas, information, and opinions
clearly and coherently (e.g., present events
and information in chronological order
when recounting a personal experience, provide instructions for a simple procedure
in the order in which the instructions need
to be carried out)

832F619BAF614A0B9A6E515E72807DCA.description:
use basic sentence structures, simple verb
tenses, and simple connecting words (e.g.,
but, and, or) when contributing to classroom
discussions and making presentations

C5607816159C4B86B8100943D90CECB8.description:
use basic vocabulary and conversational
conventions (e.g.,“Please excuse me”,
“May I ...”) correctly in classroom
discussions and presentations

FBFFC369A2794A288719A954599B8F05.description:
use vocabulary and conventions of spoken language appropriate for this grade correctly
and use the appropriate level of language in classroom discussions and presentations

6770BDAAFBB84D928FAF311274CB088A.description:
contribute ideas and opinions to formal
and informal discussions, and respond
with courtesy and respect to the contributions
of others (e.g., take turns speaking during class discussions, provide a simple
explanation when agreeing or disagreeing)

6D8AECA16FD5471D92AD0EEDC25E4D6D.description:
identify some of the characteristics of
formal and informal oral and oral-visual
communications, as well as some of the
basic techniques used to convey messages
(e.g., intonation and pauses in voice recordings,
the use of visual aids in speeches,
background music and sound effects in
radio and television shows)

019508262F2047E5B965DFFBA136DC9D.description:
identify the important ideas, information,
and/or messages in oral and oral-visual
communications, restating them in their
own words

44D8AEBC328F4A99BFDC1604DB2C8575.description:
recognize that oral and oral-visual communications
have a purpose, and identify
that purpose (e.g., to obtain information, to
follow simple verbal instructions, to respond
to comprehension questions) when listening
and viewing

64518DD50D8E41D69694C686C0F20AE7.description:
recognize and use some basic active listening
strategies (e.g., stop what they are
doing, look at the speaker)

30C0961042044B88B0F3B867802F7E12.description:
use active listening strategies and a range of thinking skills to comprehend and respond
to a variety of oral and oral-visual communications
